definition:
The [*dilogarithm function*]{} $$\begin{aligned}
\mbox{Li}_2(x) \;=:\; \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{x^n}{n^2},\end{aligned}$$
studied already by Leibniz, is a special case of the [*polylogarithm
function*]{}
$$\mbox{Li}_s(x) \;=:\; \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{x^n}{n^s}.$$ The radius
of convergence of the series (1) is 1, whence the definition (1) is
valid also in the unit disc of the complex plane. For $0 \le x \le 1$,
the equation (1) is apparently equivalent to $$\begin{aligned}
\mbox{Li}_2(x) \;=:\; -\int_0^x\frac{\ln(1\!-\!t)}{t}\,dt,\end{aligned}$$
(cf. logarithm series of $\ln(1\!-\!x)$). The analytic continuation of
$\mbox{Li}_2$ for $|z| \ge 1$ can be made by $$\begin{aligned}
\mbox{Li}_2(z) \;=:\; -\int_0^z\frac{\log(1\!-\!t)}{t}\,dt.\end{aligned}$$
Thus $\mbox{Li}_2(z)$ is a multivalued analytic function of $z$. Its
[*principal branch*]{} is single-valued and is got by taking the
principal branch of the complex logarithm; then
$$z \;\in\; \mathbb{C}\!\smallsetminus\![1,\,\infty[, \quad 0 < \arg(z\!-\!1) < 2\pi.$$\
For real values of $x$ we have $$\begin{aligned}
\mbox{Im}(\mbox{Li}_2(x)) \;=\;
\begin{cases}
\;0 \qquad\mbox{for}\;\; x \le 1,\\
-\pi\ln{x} \;\;\mbox{for}\;\; x > 1.
\end{cases}\end{aligned}$$ According to (2), the derivative of the
dilogarithm is $$\mbox{Li}'_2(x) \;=\; \frac{-\ln(1\!-\!x)}{x}.$$ In
terms of the Bernoulli numbers, the dilogarithm function has a series
expansion more rapidly converging than (1): $$\begin{aligned}
\mbox{Li}_2(x) \;=\; \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}B_{n-1}\frac{(-\ln(1\!-\!x))^n}{n!} 
\qquad (|\ln(1\!-\!x)| < 2\pi)\end{aligned}$$

**Some functional equations and values**
$$\mbox{Li}_2(z)+\mbox{Li}_2(-z) \;=\; \frac{1}{2}\mbox{Li}_2(z^2),$$
$$\mbox{Li}_2(z)+\mbox{Li}_2\left(\frac{1}{z}\right) \;=\; -\frac{1}{2}(\log(-z))^2-\frac{\pi^2}{6},$$
$$\mbox{Li}_2(iz)-i\mbox{Li}_2(z) \;=\; \frac{1}{4}\mbox{Li}_2(-z^2),$$
$$\mbox{Li}_2(1) \;=\; \frac{\pi^2}{6}, \quad
\mbox{Li}_2(2) \;=\; \frac{\pi^2}{4}-i\pi\ln{2}, \quad
\mbox{Li}_2(i) \;=\; -\frac{\pi^2}{48}-i\,G$$ Here, $G$ is Catalan’s
constant.\
